EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  9.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:05 p.m. on the Provisions of the Charter School Petition of Green Technology to Consider the Level of Support for Each Petition by Teachers Employed by the District, Other Employees of the District, and Parents
BACKGROUND
	 
Pursuant to Education Code 47605 a public hearing is required within 30 days following the submission of a charter school petition to the district.  The petitions were submitted to the district on June 24, 2011.  When requested by the district, Green Technology granted the District an extension of time for the required public hearing. 
	 
During the public hearing, the Governing Board of the school district shall consider the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district and parents.  The governing board shall either grant or deny the charters within 60 days of receipt of the petition; however, the date may be extended if both parties agree to the extension.  Such agreement has been reached and at the September 15, 2011, Board Meeting the Governing Board shall make its determination.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To Be Determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To Be Determined
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Hold public hearing to consider level of support for the petition submitted by Green Technology.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.02 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Response to Santa Clara County Civil Grand Jury Report: 
East Side Union High School District's Progress in Response to the Fiscal Crisis & Management Assistance Team Audit, and Status of Implementation of Changes to Contracting Practices in Response to FCMAT Audit and Civil Grand Jury Reports
	 
	 
	 
On June 16, 2011, the Santa Clara County Civil Grand Jury issued its report: “East Side Union High School District's Progress in Response to the Fiscal Crisis & Management Assistance Team Audit”.  Pursuant to the California Penal Code section 933.05, the District shall within 90 days indicate one of the following:
	 
1. The District agrees with the finding.
	 
2. The District disagrees wholly or partially with the finding, in which case the response shall specify the portion of the finding that is disputed and shall include an explanation of the reasons therefor.
  
(b) For purposes of subdivision (b) of Section 933, as to each grand jury recommendation, the District shall report one of the following actions:
	 
(1) The recommendation has been implemented, with a summary regarding the implemented action.
	 
(2) The recommendation has not yet been implemented, but will be implemented in the future, with a timeframe for implementation.
	 
(3) The recommendation requires further analysis, with an explanation and the scope and parameters of an analysis or study, and a timeframe for the matter to be prepared for discussion by the officer or head of the agency or department being investigated or reviewed, including the governing body of the public agency when applicable. This timeframe shall not exceed six months from the date of publication of the grand jury report.
	 
(4) The recommendation will not be implemented because it is not warranted or is not reasonable, with an explanation therefor.
	 
	 
Attached is a draft response for the Board’s consideration and approval.  In addition, Internal Auditor Ian Marsh will report on the status of implementation of the FCMAT recommendations.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board consider and approve the draft response to the Santa Clara County Civil Grand Jury.

SUBJECT:
California School Boards Association (CSBA) Candidate Nominations for Directors-at-Large: American Indian and Black
	 
	 
The California School Boards Association (CSBA) is currently accepting nominations for Directors-at-Large: American Indian and Black. The election will take place at CSBA's Delegate Assembly meeting at the San Diego Marriott Marquis Hotel on November 30 - December 1, 2011. Nominations for Directors-at-Large must be made by a Board Member from a CSBA member district or county office of education. Directors-at-Large serve a two-year term and take office immediately upon the close of the Association's Annual Education Conference. 
	 
The Board is requested to submit nominations to CSBA for Directors-at-Large: American Indian and Black.

Not Applicable

Not Applicable

It is recommend that the Board of Trustees submit nominations to CSBA for Directors-at-Large: American Indian and Black.

Item:  9.07
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Opening of Sealed Proposals Received by District for Proposed Cellular and Wireless Communication Antenna Sites at District Facilities per Board Resolution #2010/2011-43
	 
	 
At the June 16, 2011, Regular Board Meeting the Board approved by two-thirds majority vote Resolution 2010/2011-43 (the “Resolution”) declaring the District’s intention to lease certain District property for installation of cellular and wireless communication antenna.  Notice of the Resolution was published and posted as required by law. The Resolution and the published and posted Notice of Intention to Lease specified that the District would receive sealed proposals to lease from interested parties up to 5:00 p.m. on August 29, 2011. The Resolution further specified that the sealed proposals would be opened the next day at the time of the Board’s August 30th meeting. Pursuant to Education Code sections 17472 and 17473, all sealed proposals received by the District in accordance with the Resolution and the Notice of Intention to Lease shall be opened, examined and declared by the Board in public session. Before accepting the sealed proposals, the Board shall call for oral bids upon the terms outlined in Section 17473.
At the time of the August 30, 2011, Board meeting, Administration will present to the Board all sealed proposals received by the District in accordance with the Resolution and the Notice of Intention to Lease. 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Lease - Revenue to be Determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees open, examine and declare all sealed proposals to lease received by the District in accordance with the Resolution and the Notice of Intention to Lease.

Item:  10.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction; and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
					 
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Update, Discussion and/or Action regarding Chinese Language as an Elective
	 
Instructional Services and the Local Chinese community have moved forward with the design and support of the new Chinese Language program. The focus for 2011-12 school year is to create the program and curriculum so that the program can start in the Fall of 2012-13. The following steps have been taken so far:
	 
The California Foreign Language Project (CFLP) has been contacted to design a Chinese Language program for East Side. We have received a verbal commitment from the president of the CFLP that they will work with East Side on this project. The CFLP operates out of Stanford University and the contract for services between the CFLP and ESUHSD is being reviewed by Stanford officials. We have been told to expect the contract sometime in September for our review. Upon our approval, it will be submitted to the Board for official approval.
The creation of the program will cost the district an estimated $50,000. and once created will operate under normal expenditures.
Mark Mao and the local Chinese community have plans in motion to begin soliciting donations to help defray the cost of the program design. An account with the East Side Foundation has been setup to receive funds to support the program. Lorraine Guerin has created letters and a flyer that the local community can use to help in their solicitation efforts.

SUBJECT:
Approve Requests for Physical Education Exemption
	 
	 
Description:
Education Code Section 5124(c) and Board Policy 6142.7 state that the governing board of a school district or the office of the county superintendent of a county may grant permanent exemption from courses in physical education if the pupil complies with any one of the following:
	 
Is 16 years of age or older and has been enrolled in grade 10 for one or more academic years.
Is enrolled as a postgraduate pupil.
Is enrolled in a juvenile home, ranch, camp school where pupils are scheduled for recreation and exercise.
	 
Additionally, students must have completed 9th grade physical education and have satisfactorily met at least five of the six standards of the physical performance test pursuant to section 60800.  Students under this exemption are not allowed to attend fewer total hours of classes if he or she elects not to enroll in a physical education course.
	 
Alternative options through summer sessions are no longer available thus making it impossible for said students to complete specific requirements without granting this exemption.
The recommended students meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in Education Code 51241(c):
	 
Student A
Student B
Student C
Student D
Student E
Student F
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
	N/A
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended physical education exemptions.

SUBJECT:
Receive First Reading of New Board Policy #6180 Small Learning Communities  Board Policy 
	 
The guidelines of the federal education code for Smaller Learning Communities require that the program have open access to all students and that districts and schools cannot select specific subgroups of students based on any demographic or achievement data to enroll in the program. In order to continue to receive Smaller Learning Communities federal grant funds the Board of Trustees must enact a board policy guaranteeing open access to the Smaller Learning Communities in the East Side Union High School District. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION: 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive and review the first reading of Board Policy #6180 Smaller Learning Communities.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  10.04
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Robert Ibarra, Coordinator of Professional Development/Migrant Education
					 
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive the Second Valenzuela/CASHEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period Covering April 1 through June 30, 2011 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
	 
Background
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela/CASHEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela/CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by the general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from April 1, 2011 through June 30, 2011.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the second Quarterly Valenzuela/CASHEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering April 1, 2011 through June 30, 2011, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the second Quarterly Valenzuela/CASHEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering April 1, 2011 through June 30, 2011, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

FROM:

SUBJECT:
Approve Inter-District Attendance Agreement with the Listed School Districts
	 
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District is requesting authorization to enter into a mutual Inter-District Attendance Agreement with the school districts listed below, pursuant to California Education Code Section 46600 and Assembly Bill 2444.
	 
Campbell Union High School District
Castro Valley Unified School District
Fremont Unified School District
Fremont Union School District
Gilroy Unified School District
Hayward Unified School District
Los Gatos-Saratoga Joint Union School District
Milpitas Unified School District
Morgan Hill Unified School District
Mountain View-Los Altos School District
New Haven Unified School District
Newark Unified School District
Palo Alto Unified School District
Pleasanton Unified School District
Salinas Union High School District
San Francisco Unified School District
San Jose Unified School District
San Lorenzo Valley Unified School District
Santa Clara Unified School District
Santa Cruz City High School District
Sequoia Union High School District
	 
The term of this agreement shall be effective July 1, 2011, and shall terminate on June 30, 2016.  An inter-district transfer permit issued under this agreement is only valid for one year.  A student who attends another school district other than his or her district of residence pursuant to an inter-district transfer permit under this agreement shall reapply annually for a new inter-district transfer permit each year.   The requirement to reapply for an inter-district transfer permit each school year does not apply to a student who is attending and enrolled in a school district other than his or her district of residence pursuant to an inter-district transfer permit and who will be entering grades 11 or 12 in the subsequent school year.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize entering into mutual Inter-District Attendance Agreements with the above listed school districts until June 30, 2016.

SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-02 Inter-Fund Temporary Transfers for Cash Flow Purposes
			 
			 
Education Code Section 42603, provides for a district’s Governing Board to make temporary transfers from one fund to another for the purpose of meeting payment obligations.  However, these transfers are required to be repaid within the same fiscal year unless the transfer takes place within the final 120 calendar days of the fiscal year.
			 
The attached resolution will give the District the flexibility of temporarily transferring cash from other funds if needed to meet the obligations of the General Fund until property taxes are received in December and April of this fiscal year.
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
No increase in District Expenses
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt resolution 2011/1012-02 Inter-Fund Temporary Transfers for Cash Flow Purposes.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.05
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Award/Acceptance of Proposals to Lease District Sites for Cellular and Wireless Communication Antenna Purposes per Board Resolution #2010/2011-43
	 
	 
At the June 16, 2011, Regular Board Meeting, the Board approved by two-thirds majority vote Resolution 2010/2011-43 (the “Resolution”) declaring the District’s intention to lease certain District property for installation of cellular and wireless communication antenna. Notice of the Resolution was published and posted as required by law. The Resolution and the published and posted Notice of Intention to Lease specified that the District would receive sealed proposals to lease from interested parties up to 5:00 p.m. on August 29, 2011. Pursuant to Education Code sections 17472 and 17473, all sealed proposals received by the District in accordance with the Resolution and the Notice of Intention to Lease shall be opened, examined and declared by the Board in public session. Before accepting the sealed proposals, the Board shall call for oral bids upon the terms outlined in Section 17473.
	At the time of the August 30, Board meeting, Administration will present to the Board all sealed proposals received by the District in accordance with the Resolution and the Notice of Intention to Lease.
	Pursuant to Education Code section 17529, a school district may enter into a lease agreement for the joint use of operating school sites provided the Board first determines that the joint occupancy/use of such property will not: (1) interfere with the education program or activities of any school or class conducted upon the real property or in any building; (2) unduly disrupt the residents in the surrounding neighborhood; and (3) jeopardize the safety of the children of the school. At the September 17, 2009, Regular Board Meeting, the Board held a public hearing to solicit community input on the potential leasing of District property for such purposes.
	At the time of the August 30, meeting, and per the earlier agenda item for the opening of sealed proposals, the Board will open all sealed proposals received by the District. Once opened, the proposals will be reviewed by staff and a recommendation made to the Board. Final acceptance of the Board may be made by majority vote at the time of the August 30, meeting (provided the Board first makes the determinations set forth in the preceding paragraph). Alternatively, the Board may reject any and all received bids (either written or oral) and withdraw the property from lease if it deems such action to be for the best public interest. (Education Code section 17476).   
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Lease - Revenue to be Determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that all sealed proposals to lease received by the District in accordance with the Resolution and the Notice of Intention to Lease be reviewed by staff.
	Administration recommends that the Board find that the joint occupancy/use of District as proposed in the Resolution will not: (1) Interfere with the education program or activities of any school or class conducted upon the real property or in any building; (2) unduly disrupt the residents in the surrounding neighborhood; (3) jeopardize the safety of the children of the school as indicated by the independent analysis for each installation performed by Hammett & Edison, Inc.
	It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept such proposals as may be recommended by staff, subject to the parties executing a final lease agreement in form satisfactory to the District and that any such agreement(s) be presented to the Board for ratification at the time of the next regular Board meeting.

TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Mac Cage, Interim Director of Information Technology in Consultation with SGI
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Revised Information Technology Budget for Measure E Bond Program
		 
On June 18, 2009, the Board approved a revised Measure E Bond Program, Project Summary Worksheet for Information Technology (Exhibit 1). This Worksheet defines 13 individual bond funded projects that were presented in priority order for Board consideration. Consistent with the District’s Technology Plan, the singular goal of these 13 projects is to provide a 21st Century capacity for the instruction, administration, and support requirements of the District.
In the two years since Board approval, the Information Technology Department has diligently advanced the objectives of these 13 projects through acquisition and installation of material and equipment and the provision of related services. It is well understood that the rapid pace of change in technology makes it difficult to precisely predict technical details and costs of implementation for such a plan past a year or two. It has become increasingly apparent that many of the 13 projects are interconnected in ways that could not have been anticipated at the outset.
As a result, financial tracking and project management has become challenging. To help address this, it is proposed that the scope of the 13 projects be combined into 9 projects that are easier to administer. The attached presentation summarizes these changes and concludes with a “Revised Measure E Information Technology Budget”. Staff will be on hand to make a brief presentation and address any questions that may arise.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the attached "Revised Information Technology Budget for Measure E" consistent with the District's Technology Plan.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  12.07
			 
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Survey of School Districts Legal Expense/Costs
			 
Based on a review of the data, the district incurred total legal costs for fiscal year 2010-11 of 1.23 million.  From the total $1.23 million incurred in FY 2010-11, $373,000 was attributed to General-Legal costs which include costs related to special education, employment, and other general litigation expenses.  The remaining $863,000 is related to legal expenses associated with the districts bond and construction program.  In FY 2009-10, the district's legal costs totaled $794,000.  In comparing FY 2009-10 with FY 2010-11 legal costs, the district's general legal costs declined by $122,000 and the bond/construction legal cost increased by $564,000.  A review of billing invoices indicate that most of the increase in bond/construction costs for FY 2010-11 was related to the KMS litigation. 
			 
In comparing the district's legal costs with those from districts of similar size, the findings suggest that the district's general-legal costs for FY 2010-11 compared favorably with those districts.  In regard to bond/construction related legal costs, the district is above the average for the fiscal year ending 2010-11.  As was noted earlier, the increase in bond/construction related costs was primarily attributable to the KMS litigation.
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept survey report as presented.

SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Months of June and July 2011
				 
				 
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of June and July 2011, in response to board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.

Not Applicable
